articles.content:
Click to expand Image United Nations Social Summit in Doha, Qatar, 2025. © 2025 Sylvain Aubry/Human Rights Watch

At the second United Nations Social Summit in Qatar this week, dozens of governments adopted the Doha Political Declaration, renewing their commitments to tackle poverty, create decent work, combat discrimination, expand access to social security, and fulfill human rights. Governments should now match their words with action by enabling the necessary resources to realize these commitments, and next week’s second round of negotiations for a UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation are an excellent opportunity.

Amidst growing geopolitical tensions, the Doha Political Declaration reaffirms the centrality of human rights for social development, and emphasizes the equal value of all civil, political, economic, social, and cultural rights, including the right to development. It affirms that “social development and social justice cannot be attained in the absence of peace and security or in the absence of respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms.”

Importantly, the declaration affirms the importance of the rights to housing, food, health, education, an adequate standard of living, water, and sanitation.

Crucially, it also emphasizes the need to close the financing gap to achieve these objectives. Ongoing negotiations for a first-ever UN tax convention are a key chance to make progress on this front, as well as states’ agreement in July’s Sevilla commitment “to engage constructively in the negotiations on the United Nations framework convention on international tax cooperation and its protocols and encourage support for the process.”

The UN tax convention negotiations mark a groundbreaking process that started in August this year. They will continue in Nairobi next week and are set to conclude by September 2027. The convention could enable countries to raise an additional hundreds of billions of dollars through fairer and more transparent rules for taxing corporations and wealthy individuals, and effectively addressing tax evasion and illicit financial flows.

This money could help fund rights like education, health care, and social security, which is particularly important as the UN anticipates a large financing gap that undermines the prospects of achieving the global Sustainable Development Goals.

The commitments made in Doha and the progress that could be made to secure the resources governments need to fund them in Nairobi have a particular resonance as youth in Morocco and other countries have taken the streets in the last months to ask for economic justice and quality public services.

Now is the chance for states to put promises into action by enabling governments to have the resources they need to deliver on human rights.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant global commitment by dozens of governments at the UN Social Summit to advance social development and human rights, including tackling poverty, discrimination, and expanding social security. It highlights a groundbreaking UN tax convention negotiation that could generate substantial funding to support these rights and Sustainable Development Goals, representing a broad, meaningful impact on global social justice and human rights.
articles.personality_title: World leaders renew commitment to fight poverty and support human rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2025, the United Nations held its second Social Summit in Doha, Qatar. This meeting brought together many countries to discuss important social issues like poverty, discrimination, and access to basic services.

**What happened** – At the summit, dozens of governments agreed on the Doha Political Declaration. This document promises to work harder to reduce poverty, create good jobs, fight discrimination, and improve social security and human rights. They also highlighted the need to protect rights to housing, food, health, education, water, and sanitation. Next week, talks will continue in Nairobi on a new UN tax agreement. This plan aims to create fairer tax rules to stop companies and wealthy people from avoiding taxes.

**Impact** – This agreement is important because it could raise hundreds of billions of dollars for countries. That money can help pay for schools, healthcare, and social programs, especially in places that struggle to fund these services. The declaration also stresses that social progress depends on peace, security, and respect for all human rights. These commitments come at a time when young people in countries like Morocco are demanding fair economic opportunities and better public services.

**What's next step** – The tax negotiations in Nairobi will continue and are expected to finish by 2027. If successful, they will give governments more money to support social development. Governments now face the challenge of turning their promises into real actions and ensuring resources reach the people who need them.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Governments worldwide have renewed their promise to reduce poverty and protect human rights, with new tax talks offering a way to fund these important goals.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les dirigeants mondiaux renouvellent leur engagement contre la pauvreté et pour les droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2025, les Nations Unies ont organisé leur deuxième Sommet social à Doha, au Qatar. Cette réunion a rassemblé de nombreux pays pour discuter de questions sociales importantes comme la pauvreté, la discrimination et l’accès aux services essentiels.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors du sommet, des dizaines de gouvernements ont adopté la Déclaration politique de Doha. Ce document promet de lutter plus efficacement contre la pauvreté, de créer des emplois décents, de combattre la discrimination et d’améliorer la sécurité sociale et les droits humains. Ils ont aussi souligné l’importance des droits au logement, à la nourriture, à la santé, à l’éducation, à l’eau et à l’assainissement. La semaine prochaine, des négociations auront lieu à Nairobi pour un nouvel accord fiscal de l’ONU. Ce plan vise à instaurer des règles fiscales plus justes pour empêcher les entreprises et les riches d’échapper aux impôts.

**Impact** – Cet accord est important car il pourrait permettre de collecter des centaines de milliards de dollars pour les pays. Cet argent aidera à financer les écoles, les soins de santé et les programmes sociaux, surtout dans les pays qui ont du mal à les financer. La déclaration rappelle aussi que le progrès social dépend de la paix, de la sécurité et du respect de tous les droits humains. Ces engagements interviennent à un moment où les jeunes de pays comme le Maroc demandent des opportunités économiques justes et de meilleurs services publics.

**Prochaine étape** – Les négociations fiscales à Nairobi vont se poursuivre et devraient se terminer en 2027. Si elles réussissent, elles permettront aux gouvernements de disposer de plus de ressources pour soutenir le développement social. Les gouvernements doivent maintenant transformer leurs promesses en actions concrètes et veiller à ce que les ressources parviennent aux personnes qui en ont besoin.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les gouvernements du monde entier ont renouvelé leur promesse de réduire la pauvreté et de protéger les droits humains, avec de nouvelles négociations fiscales offrant un moyen de financer ces objectifs importants.
articles.personality_title_es: Líderes mundiales renuevan compromiso para combatir la pobreza y apoyar los derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2025, las Naciones Unidas celebraron su segunda Cumbre Social en Doha, Qatar. Esta reunión reunió a muchos países para hablar sobre problemas sociales importantes como la pobreza, la discriminación y el acceso a servicios básicos.

**Qué pasó** – En la cumbre, decenas de gobiernos acordaron la Declaración Política de Doha. Este documento promete trabajar más para reducir la pobreza, crear empleos decentes, combatir la discriminación y mejorar la seguridad social y los derechos humanos. También destacaron la importancia de los derechos a la vivienda, la alimentación, la salud, la educación, el agua y el saneamiento. La próxima semana continuarán las conversaciones en Nairobi sobre un nuevo acuerdo fiscal de la ONU. Este plan busca crear reglas fiscales más justas para evitar que empresas y personas ricas evadan impuestos.

**Impacto** – Este acuerdo es importante porque podría recaudar cientos de miles de millones de dólares para los países. Ese dinero puede ayudar a pagar escuelas, atención médica y programas sociales, especialmente en lugares que tienen dificultades para financiar estos servicios. La declaración también subraya que el progreso social depende de la paz, la seguridad y el respeto a todos los derechos humanos. Estos compromisos llegan en un momento en que jóvenes de países como Marruecos exigen oportunidades económicas justas y mejores servicios públicos.

**Próximo paso** – Las negociaciones fiscales en Nairobi continuarán y se espera que terminen en 2027. Si tienen éxito, darán a los gobiernos más dinero para apoyar el desarrollo social. Ahora los gobiernos deben convertir sus promesas en acciones reales y asegurar que los recursos lleguen a quienes los necesitan.

**Frase clave** – Los gobiernos de todo el mundo han renovado su promesa de reducir la pobreza y proteger los derechos humanos, con nuevas conversaciones fiscales que ofrecen una forma de financiar estas importantes metas.

articles.title: Hands United: Where language meets love for Deaf immigrant families
articles.summary:

The post Hands United: Where language meets love for Deaf immigrant families first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Language, Identity & Belonging

Welcome to the second week of The Optimist Daily’s Annual Local Changemakers series. This week, we celebrate those bridging communication gaps and fighting for inclusion. Join us as we learn all about changemakers whose work speaks volumes and strives to catch the attention of a world that often forgets to listen. From linguistic equity to educational access, their compassion creates ripples of empowerment.

Today, we shine a light on Celena Ponce, a woman whose heart and hands are shaping a more just, inclusive world for Deaf immigrants and their families.

How Celena Ponce is empowering Deaf immigrant families

The impactful work of Celena Ponce began as a loving relationship between her and her goddaughter, a young Deaf Latina woman struggling to navigate an unfamiliar world. Starting Hands United, or Manos Unidas in Spanish, wasn’t just a career move; it was born out of love and compassion.

Now, the nonprofit now supports Deaf and hard-of-hearing children of immigrant families across 30 states. From ASL education to legal consultation support, Celena and her team are bridging the gap for families that are too often left out of the conversation.

“We’ve now supported around 300 families in 30 states,” Celena shared. “And we’re currently working with six Deaf immigrants—helping either through consultation with their legal team or by connecting them to the right support.”

It’s a small but mighty operation that offers classes, workshops, visual communication tools, multilingual ASL dictionaries, and legal navigation help, all for free. The nonprofit’s dedication extends to creating communication boards for immigration and detention contexts, allowing Deaf individuals to better advocate for themselves when it matters most.

Hands United doesn’t just mitigate the impact of language deprivation. It reaches over layers of exclusion and makes a path for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing community to live with dignity.

More than services: stories of trust and transformation

The weight of Hands United’s work can’t be measured solely in numbers. It’s in the relief of a parent who can finally communicate with their child. The empowerment of a Deaf immigrant who, for the first time, feels heard in court. The joy of a child signing “I love you” to their mom in their shared language.

The organization is trusted not only by the families it serves, but also by major supporters in the Deaf community. The American Society for Deaf Children (ASDC) has publicly championed Hands United for its groundbreaking work with underserved Deaf youth and immigrant communities.

“ASDC supports Hands United’s mission of bridging communication gaps for Deaf children in immigrant families,” the organization shared. “Their commitment to equity and education reflects the future we all want to build.”

Equity, heart, and a vision for more

Hands United remains free for all families, thanks to a community-powered model built on collaboration and compassion. Their bilingual website, handsunitedor.org, is filled with resources, from sign language guides to updates about workshops and events. The nonprofit’s presence is also active on Facebook, where their team shares real-time support updates and multilingual advocacy.

While their reach already spans 30 states, Celena envisions scaling further to meet families wherever they are, in every sense of the word.

From us to them: A standing ovation

This kind of change takes hands and hearts. As part of this feature, we also honor the families who have trusted Hands United, the educators who partner in solidarity, and the Deaf community leaders who uplift one another in the pursuit of a more inclusive world.

Celena, thank you for showing us what it looks like to listen deeply, teach boldly, and love in every language.

Learn more about Hands United and how you can support their work: https://handsunitedor.org/

Follow them on Instagram and YouTube for the latest updates.

articles.title: Press release - Moldova’s future is European and that future starts now
articles.summary: President Roberta Metsola was in Chișinău to address the Parliament at the start of its legislative term, where she reiterated Parliament's commitment to Moldova's European future. Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
Stimate domnule Președinte,

Stimați membri ai Parlamentului Republicii Moldova,

Dragi europeni,



În primul meu an în fruntea Parlamentului European, am venit în această sală de plen, exact în acest loc, și am spus: locul Moldovei este în Europa. Este o onoare să mă întorc aici, în acest nou mandat de Președintă a Parlamentului European, nu doar pentru a repeta acest mesaj, ci pentru a-l reînnoi.



If three years ago, we spoke of candidate status as a beginning, today I am here to speak about accession as a project. The European promise is no longer a distant idea on the horizon. We have, at this moment, a powerful window of opportunity - and there is momentum. For Moldova and its people, it is taking shape. It is real, and it is happening now. This is thanks to your country’s courage, the determination of your leaders and the conviction of your people. Thank you for this.



Dear friends, the significance of this day - November 7th - is not lost on us. Thirty-six years ago, just two days before the fall of the Berlin Wall, a small group of Moldovans - most of them young people - stood with candles in front of Soviet tanks. The old order’s show of might no longer spoke for them. They knew they had the right to choose their own destiny - and through a quiet but courageous act of defiance, they stepped up to claim it.



It's that same courage that still defines Moldova today. And so, I cannot begin without acknowledging the historic results of your parliamentary elections in September. For the third consecutive time, Moldova chose European path. And now you have a right - and a responsibility - to see this through. And I am here to say that we will be with you, as your friends, every step of the way.



Your progress is already remarkable. And the annual Enlargement Package that was published three days ago confirms precisely this. You’ve successfully completed the screening process; you’ve adopted key roadmaps to strengthen the rule of law and democratic institutions; you’ve met the conditions to open the most crucial accession negotiation clusters; and you’re well on your way to open all clusters before the end of the year. Even as disinformation, hybrid threats, and malicious attempts sought to destabilise the country, Moldova is advancing decisively on its accession path.



Mr Speaker, starting this new Parliament’s work with a session on accession sends a powerful message. In your inaugural address you called this Parliament “The European Integration Generation”, and we can see it. With President Maia Sandu’s strong leadership and the Moldovan government’s steadfast commitment to joining the European Union by 2030, you are defining a generation that will bring Moldova home to Europe.



It's an ambition that runs deeper than aligning laws or harmonising standards. You understand, perhaps better than anyone, what it means to be tested - and to stand firm when it matters most. You are the people that personify the hope of Europe.



It took real courage for you to cut dependence on Russian energy. In just a few short years, you have shown what it means to choose freedom over fear, resilience over reliance, Europe over coercion. You have proven that even when the pressure mounts, a nation can stand firm.



I am aware that taking a clear pro-European stance has not been easy for your country. It has come at a high cost - and the situation, I know, remains fragile. But choosing Europe has always meant choosing solidarity. Across our Union, Member States have already facilitated new interconnections. Together we are diversifying our energy supplies with partners that we can all trust.



This is as much in support for your country as it is a collective investment. The European Parliament was the first to call for an end to Russian energy dependence and now we are doing just that. Our decision and our direction are the same. Moldova’s future is European. And that means you will not face this journey, no matter how difficult it is, alone. You have my commitment on that.



So, if I have not been clear enough already, let me say: The European Parliament will do everything necessary to stand with you on your path towards becoming European Union Members.



Not only political - though that matters. We were the first EU Institution to call for Moldova’s candidate status. We repeatedly condemn all foreign interference that seeks to undermine your national stability. And we remain unwavering in our support for the Republic of Moldova’s sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity.



Not only financially - though that also matters. We’ve just disbursed 18.9 million Euro under our Reform and Growth Facility which follows the 270 million Euro in pre-financing. We’ve revised the EU-Moldova Free Trade Area to ensure long-term stability and to deepen your country’s integration in the Single Market. And we’ve supported Moldova’s entry into the Single Euro Payments and the ‘Roam like at home’ areas - so that young people in Moldova have the same access to opportunities - the same chance to reach their potential - as everyone else throughout Europe.



But what I am talking about is more practical support. Having been involved in my own country’s accession process, I know from experience, how important it is to have partners that are present and that are engaged. That offer hands-on support throughout the whole process.



That is why I am proud to announce that we are officially opening a Permanent Representation Office of the European Parliament in Chișinău - a clear sign of our commitment to the Eastern Partnership countries and Moldova’s journey towards EU membership. With this office, we’ll be here on the ground every day - working alongside you, supporting you, and helping you keep up the momentum.



And Mr Speaker, Members of Parliament, in a few moments I would be very much honoured to present you with a copy of this historic Decision as a lasting reminder of the moment we took our partnership to the next level. Promise made, promise delivered.



Dear friends, I know what European Union membership can mean for a country and its people. How it can lift up communities and bring concrete benefits that change lives dramatically. I want to be emphatic when I say that this is not a gesture of generosity, it is a process that benefits everyone involved. It is a win-win for all.



We’re having very serious discussions about security and defence in Europe - about what it takes to keep our people safe. But the truth is: enlargement is, was, and remains, our strongest geopolitical tool. And especially in today’s strategic reality, an enlarged European Union that is based on clear objectives, criteria and merit, is the best investment in peace, security, stability and prosperity on the European continent. Europe needs Moldova just as Moldova needs Europe.



And to be clear, this not just my view - it is what people are saying across our continent. A recent European Union survey shows a strong majority of citizens support opening the European project to new members. The percentage is even higher among young people. People don’t just want to bring Europe to Moldova. They want to bring Moldova to Europe.



Just a couple of months ago, European leaders Friedrich Merz, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Tusk gathered here in Chișinău to reaffirm our unwavering support for Moldova’s European future. It was the most powerful display of unity that showed Europe’s door is wide open. Now we need to make sure that you can step through. Destiny is calling and together we must answer.



Earlier this week, when talking about Moldova’s path towards EU membership, President Sandu said: “If this is a marathon, it must have a finish line - not moving goalposts”. And she’s right. Time and again, Moldova and its people have shown outstanding commitment, but every commitment needs purpose. It is Europe’s turn to respond - with the same clarity, the same courage, and the same belief in our shared future. The time has come to open accession negotiations.



In the meantime, we also need to be thinking about how this will change the way we operate. What works for a Union of 27 will not work for a Union of 29, for 30 or more. So while candidate countries prepare to join, we must be using this time to prepare as well. The European Parliament is not afraid to have this discussion - just last month we voted on a report to kick-start the process. Because we know we need to keep matching our commitment with action.



Dear friends, as President of the European Parliament, I’ve met a lot of people - and there have been plenty of moments that I will never ever forget. One of those moments was when I addressed the hundreds of thousands of Moldovans at the European Moldova National Assembly rally, right here, in this city.



I will never forget the sight of those European and Moldovan flags waving side by side, or the sound of voices united in one chant: “Europa este Moldova! Moldova este Europa!” The European Parliament cannot, and will not, close the door to that dream. This is a history we will write together - and I want to assure you that the European Parliament will remain with you every step of the way.



Mulțumesc.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Moldova's significant political progress and commitment towards European Union accession, highlighting broad societal benefits such as strengthened democracy, sovereignty, and economic integration. It details concrete support from the European Parliament, including financial aid and institutional presence, signaling a meaningful and hopeful advancement for Moldova's future and regional stability.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament renews strong support for Moldova’s EU membership journey
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Moldova has been working towards joining the European Union (EU) for several years. The country has faced challenges but remains determined to become a full EU member. This effort includes political reforms, economic changes, and a strong desire among Moldovans to be part of Europe.

**What happened**
On November 7, 2025, Roberta Metsola, President of the European Parliament, visited Moldova’s capital, Chișinău. She addressed the Moldovan Parliament and reaffirmed the EU’s commitment to Moldova’s future in Europe. Metsola announced the opening of a permanent European Parliament office in Chișinău to provide ongoing support. She praised Moldova for meeting important steps toward EU membership, including reforms in law and democracy, despite challenges like foreign interference.

**Impact**
This visit and the new office show a strong, practical partnership between the EU and Moldova. It means Moldova is not alone in its journey toward EU membership. The support includes financial aid, deeper economic ties, and help for Moldovan citizens to access opportunities like traveling across Europe. This commitment also highlights Moldova’s courage to choose independence and European values, even under pressure.

articles.title: The Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina Evaluated as Very Successful with the European Union Strategy for the Danube Region
articles.summary: Bosnia and Herzegovina has successfully completed a one-year presidency of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region, confirming its ability to coordinate complex regional processes and be a reliable European partner. At the closing forum in Sarajevo, it was highlighted that BiH achieved all planned goals, focusing on economic development and European integration, and handed over the presidency to Bulgaria.
articles.content:
Bosnia and Herzegovina has successfully completed a one-year presidency of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region, confirming its ability to coordinate complex regional processes and be a reliable European partner. At the closing forum in Sarajevo, it was highlighted that BiH achieved all planned goals, focusing on economic development and European integration, and handed over the presidency to Bulgaria.

Sarajevo (Fena) – The presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina of the European Union Strategy for the Danube Region (EUSDR) has been assessed as very successful, with messages that BiH has demonstrated institutional maturity, the ability to coordinate and manage complex regional processes, and has confirmed its role as a reliable European partner, it was emphasized after the official opening of the 14th EU Strategy for the Danube Region Forum (EUSDR) in Sarajevo, which also included a meeting of the foreign ministers of the Danube region, as the concluding event of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s one-year presidency of the EUSDR, which Bosnia and Herzegovina took over from the Republic of Austria last year.

The organizers of the two-day 14th EU Strategy for the Danube Region Forum, held in Sarajevo, are the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of BiH and the Directorate for European Integration of BiH.

The Minister of Foreign Affairs of BiH, Elmedin Konaković, symbolically handed over the presidency of the EUSDR to the Minister for Regional Development and Public Works of the Republic of Bulgaria, Ivan Ivanov, as Bulgaria takes over the presidency from BiH.

Addressing the media, Konaković stated that BiH has successfully passed an important test by presiding over the EU Strategy for the Danube Region and has shown that it can manage complex regional processes at the highest level in the interest of its citizens and partners.

He emphasized that all planned goals were achieved during the past year, with a special focus on economic development.

– Our priorities were primarily focused on economic aspects that contribute to the development of the economy of BiH, and thus to addressing one of our biggest problems, the emigration of young people, as well as older individuals – said Konaković.

He thanked all partners and participating countries for their support, emphasizing the importance of the Danube Strategy as a platform that connects EU member states and those aspiring to membership.

– Through this exchange of experiences with colleagues from the EU and their direct assistance, we can make some important strides, which we have done – he emphasized.

He particularly underscored the importance of the EU enlargement process and full membership of BiH, assessing that the country is “a few steps away from the historic opening of negotiations.”

In this context, he called on all political actors in BiH to understand the importance of adopting two European laws, the law on the court and the law on the High Judicial and Prosecutorial Council, and to appoint a chief negotiator with the EU as a final step, who, as he said, must be extremely pro-European oriented.

The Director of the Directorate for European Integration of BiH, Elvira Habota, stated that the presidency of BiH of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region was one of the key tasks on the European path of our country, through which BiH demonstrated institutional maturity and the ability to coordinate the activities of 14 member states of the strategy.

Habota noted that during the first presidency of BiH in this initiative, a series of activities and events were organized that brought together more than 350 representatives from institutions, civil and business sectors, while the concluding Forum in Sarajevo gathered more than 400 actors and partners from the EU and member states of the Danube Strategy.

– The presidency confirmed that BiH can be a center of regional cooperation and a reliable European partner. We have shown that we are not just part of the European integration process, but also its active creator – she emphasized.

As she stated, BiH focused its presidency on topics that reflect the priorities of the EU and member states, among which support for the EU enlargement process and strengthening cooperation between member states and those in the accession process are particularly important.

– The Danube Strategy has provided us with a range of opportunities, primarily the chance to learn, exchange experiences, and build partnerships that bring us closer to the European Union. Activities involving youth, civil society, and entrepreneurs were of particular significance – emphasized the director of the Directorate for European Integration.

The Minister for Regional Development and Public Works of the Republic of Bulgaria, Ivan Ivanov, also addressed the media, stating that Bulgaria will continue the presidency of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region in the same spirit of partnership that BiH successfully led this process during the past year.

He thanked his colleagues from BiH for their dedication and commitment during their presidency of the Strategy, leaving it with a clear focus and concrete results.

– As Bulgaria takes over the presidency of the Danube Strategy, we do so with deep respect for the work invested during the previous presidency and with a strong sense of shared responsibility – said Ivanov.

He emphasized that the main priorities of the Bulgarian presidency will be to reduce regional disparities and create greater opportunities across the Danube region.

– We believe that by strengthening the Danube region, we enhance our diversities and our ability to turn them into a driving force for common progress and solidarity – emphasized the Bulgarian minister.

Ivanov added that no region or community should be neglected and that Bulgaria will work to make the Strategy an even stronger platform for cooperation, solidarity, and connecting policies, financing, and people.

The Head of the European Union Delegation in BiH, Ambassador Luigi Soreca, emphasized that strengthening cross-border cooperation is at the very heart of the reasons for the establishment of the EU and that the EU Strategy for the Danube Region helps member states and candidate countries build stronger cooperation and ensure visible benefits for their citizens.

Soreca also pointed out that the EU will continue to align macro-regional priorities with existing financial mechanisms, particularly taking into account the needs of youth and new generations.

– The best guarantee for greater prosperity and stability, both for BiH and for the entire Danube region, is a shared future within the European Union – he said.

He reminded that the EU presented the Progress Report for all candidate countries this week and that the recent visits of high European officials Kaja Kallas and Marta Kos to BiH once again confirmed that EU enlargement is “the greatest European investment in peace, stability, and hope.”

– Together we can turn opportunities into real progress for the Western Balkans and the entire Danube region – Soreca concluded.

At the meeting, the Sarajevo-Danube Declaration was also adopted, which is said to show a common vision for the Danube region. (7.11.)

articles.personality_title: Bosnia and Herzegovina successfully leads EU strategy for Danube region
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) took on the presidency of the European Union Strategy for the Danube Region (EUSDR) for one year. This strategy is a plan that helps countries along the Danube River work together on issues like economic growth and regional cooperation.

**What happened**
From last year until recently, BiH led the EUSDR, coordinating activities among 14 member countries. They held meetings and events involving over 400 participants to discuss economic development and European integration. At a closing forum in Sarajevo, BiH handed over the presidency to Bulgaria. Officials said BiH met all its goals, especially focusing on improving the economy to reduce the emigration of young and older people.

**Impact**
This successful presidency showed that BiH can manage complex regional projects and be a trusted partner in Europe. It helped the country build stronger ties with EU members and boosted its progress toward joining the European Union. The work also involved youth, businesses, and civil society, creating new opportunities and partnerships.

**What's next step**
Bulgaria will now lead the EUSDR, aiming to reduce differences between regions and create more opportunities across the Danube area. Meanwhile, BiH is expected to continue moving forward with EU membership talks by adopting important laws and appointing a chief negotiator.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Bosnia and Herzegovina’s year leading the EU Danube Strategy proved its ability to unite countries for economic growth and closer ties with Europe.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bosnie-Herzégovine réussit sa présidence de la stratégie européenne pour la région du Danube

De l'année dernière jusqu'à récemment, la BiH a dirigé l’EUSDR, coordonnant les activités de 14 pays membres. Cette présidence réussie a montré que la BiH peut gérer des projets régionaux complexes et être un partenaire fiable en Europe. Cela a renforcé les liens avec les membres de l’UE et accéléré les progrès vers l’adhésion à l’Union européenne. Le travail a aussi impliqué les jeunes, les entreprises et la société civile, créant de nouvelles opportunités et partenariats.

La Bulgarie prendra désormais la tête de l’EUSDR, avec pour objectifs de réduire les disparités régionales et de créer davantage d’opportunités dans la région du Danube. La présidence de la Bosnie-Herzégovine à la stratégie européenne pour le Danube a prouvé sa capacité à unir les pays pour la croissance économique et des liens plus étroits avec l’Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: Bosnia y Herzegovina lidera con éxito la estrategia de la UE para la región del Danubio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Bosnia y Herzegovina (BiH) tuvo la presidencia durante un año de la Estrategia de la Unión Europea para la Región del Danubio (EUSDR). Esta estrategia ayuda a los países a lo largo del río Danubio a trabajar juntos en temas como el crecimiento económico y la cooperación regional.

**Qué sucedió**
Desde el año pasado hasta hace poco, BiH dirigió la EUSDR, coordinando actividades entre 14 países miembros. Organizaron reuniones y eventos con más de 400 participantes para hablar sobre desarrollo económico e integración europea. En un foro de cierre en Sarajevo, BiH entregó la presidencia a Bulgaria. Los funcionarios dijeron que BiH cumplió todas sus metas, especialmente enfocándose en mejorar la economía para reducir la emigración de jóvenes y personas mayores.

**Impacto**
Esta exitosa presidencia mostró que BiH puede manejar proyectos regionales complejos y ser un socio confiable en Europa. Ayudó al país a fortalecer sus lazos con miembros de la UE y a avanzar en su proceso para unirse a la Unión Europea. El trabajo también involucró a jóvenes, empresas y sociedad civil, creando nuevas oportunidades y asociaciones.

**Próximo paso**
Bulgaria liderará ahora la EUSDR, con el objetivo de reducir las diferencias entre regiones y crear más oportunidades en la zona del Danubio. Mientras tanto, se espera que BiH continúe avanzando en las negociaciones para ser miembro de la UE con la adopción de leyes importantes y el nombramiento de un negociador principal.

**Resumen en una frase**
La presidencia de Bosnia y Herzegovina en la estrategia de la UE para el Danubio demostró su capacidad para unir países y fomentar el crecimiento económico y la integración europea.
